Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Structured Signal Modeling via Nonconvex Optimization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many problems in modern signal processing and data analysis can be cast as searching for a structured, low-dimensional model for observed data. Images, audio signals, video sequences, and more, can be modeled as sparse in an appropriate dictionary. Scientific data, from neural spike sorting to microscopy, can be modeled as superpositions of characteristic patterns, translated over space. Learned data representations yield excellent results on a variety of classical problems in image processing and vision, and are also play a crucial role in recent breakthroughs in signal classification and computational scientific discovery. In contrast, much less is known theoretically about the properties of learned representations, and of algorithms for learning them. This project develops theory and dedicated optimization algorithms, which are guaranteed, under appropriate conditions, to provide good representations for observed signals.

The investigators study theoretical and computational aspects of a family of problems, including sparse dictionary learning, sparse deconvolution, and convolutional dictionary learning. The natural formulations of these problems are nonconvex. The goal of the project is to develop geometric insights into these nonconvex problems, and to use these insights to develop recovery theory and scalable, efficient algorithms. Key challenges include understanding the properties of local and global minima, and developing efficient algorithms that avoid stalling near saddle points. The algorithms are demonstrated on real signal data arising in image classification and scientific imaging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learned data representations play a critical role in many areas of science and engineering. The move from hand-designed signal representations to data-driven approaches has enabled more effective methods for a wide range of problems in image and video processing, sensing and signal acquisition and computational scientific discovery. However, these advances come at a price: the optimization problem associated with best representing a given dataset is typically not convex, and it is challenging to find efficient methods that guarantee to produce high quality solutions.

 

Intellectual merit. This project studied the geometric structure of these data representation problems, with an aim towards developing efficient, guaranteed methods. A key finding is that many optimization problems in data representation have a benign geometric structure, which enables efficient methods to find globally optimal solutions, independent of initialization. Namely, every locally optimal solution is actually globally optimal, and saddle points exhibit strict negative curvature. This structure obtains for problems of concise data representation (dictionary learning), signal recovery from nonlinear measurements (phase retrieval) and data modeling with repeated motifs (blind deconvolution). For each of these examples, the project provided guaranteed methods that succeed in new regimes (e.g., are capable of learning more complicated representations) and provides the first analysis of the global geometry of the associated optimization problems. The project developed efficient optimization methods which leverage these geometric properties, including trust region methods and methods based on curvilinear search, and proved that for problems with this benign geometric structure, these methods efficiently obtain globally optimal solutions. It also showed how scalable first order methods can implicitly leverage the curvature structure of certain nonconvex problems to obtain globally optimal solutions.

 

Broader impacts. Nonconvex optimization plays a critical role in a wide range of areas, including machine learning, microscopy, and neuroscience. The methods developed in this project perform well on data sets from across these areas. Moreover, the geometric analysis developed in this project gives insights into how to formulate problems that are amenable to global optimization (e.g., how to choose appropriate constraints and regularizers). The PI is currently collaborating with experts in microscopy, astronomy and neuroscience to disseminate these findings into these domains. The key findings of the project have also been distilled into new educational materials (course modules, bootcamp lectures) and are being incorporated into a forthcoming textbook on high-dimensional data analysis. Visualizations of the project?s findings have also been incorporated into interactive outreach modules that aim to expose high school students from underrepresented groups to engineering.
